title: Corrupt Master Log
text: Corrupt Master Log 30 March 2023 13:32 While restarting the MS SQL service you will get an error and MS SQL service on the server won't start . If you check the event viewer in Windows you may find a similar error to the below. The log scan number passed to log scan in database master is not valid. This error may indicate data corruption or that the log file (.ldf) does not match the data file (.mdf). If this error occurred during replication, re-create the publication. Otherwise, restore from backup if the problem results in a failure during startup. This usually occurs when the master.mdf or the mastlog.ldf gets corrupt . Best practice in this case would be to restore from backup. However it is not always the case that the master database is backed up. In order to solve the issue we have two options ; Using Setup to Recreate System Databases Open an elevated command prompt and from the bootstrap directory- "C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\\Setup Bootstrap\" (replace with the right version and with the right release SQL Version Cheat Sheet may help you identify which version you need) run the following command substituting your SQL instance name, a windows account to have administrative rights and a secure password for SA where indicated. Before running this make sure you have copies of the existing model and msdb databases saved off somewhere safe! .\setup /ACTION=REBUILDDATABASE /INSTANCENAME= /SQLSYSADMINACCOUNTS= /SAPWD= All being well this we recreate the master db with the details provided in the command. You should then replace the model and msdb files with the good ones you moved previously. The MS SQL service should then start. NOTE : You may be required to reattach the existing databases to the instance depending on what was lost when the master db corrupted. If the above fails then there is another method but it has pitfalls. Manually Recreating the Master Database The below method will work however it will remove all users from the instance making logging in and administration very difficult. This method should be used as a last ditch effort to get the system up and running. It may be preferable to reinstall SQL completely over the below. Before running this make sure you have copies of the existing model and msdb databases saved off somewhere safe! Navigate to your instance folder "C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\MSSQL.1\MSSQL " , there you will find a folder called Template Data, copy the master.mdf and mastlog.ldf from Template Data and replace it in "C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\MSSQL.1\MSSQL\Data" NOTE : You WILL be required to reattach the existing databases to the instance. You WILL be required to recreate any SQL users Restart the MS SQL Service and it will come back online
description:
Corrupt Master Log

30 March 2023

13:32

 

While restarting the MS SQL service you will get an error and MS SQL service on the server won't start . If you check the event viewer in Windows  you may find a similar error to the below.

 

The log scan number passed to log scan in database master is not valid. This error may indicate data corruption or that the log file (.ldf) does not match the data file (.mdf). If this error occurred during replication, re-create the publication. Otherwise, restore from backup if the problem results in a failure during startup.

 

This usually occurs when the master.mdf or the mastlog.ldf gets corrupt . 

 

Best practice in this case would be to restore from backup. However it is not always the case that the master database is backed up.

 

In order to solve the issue we have two options ; 

 

Using Setup to Recreate System Databases

 

Open an elevated command prompt and from the bootstrap directory- "C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\<nnn>\Setup Bootstrap\<release>" (replace <nnn> with the right version and <release> with the right release SQL Version Cheat Sheet may help you identify which version you need) run the following command substituting your SQL instance name, a windows account to have administrative rights and a secure password for SA where indicated. 

 

Before running this make sure you have copies of the existing model and msdb databases saved off somewhere safe!

 

.\setup /ACTION=REBUILDDATABASE /INSTANCENAME=<instance_name> /SQLSYSADMINACCOUNTS=<admin_account> /SAPWD=<sa_password>

 

All being well this we recreate the master db with the details provided in the command. You should then replace the model and msdb files with the good ones you moved previously. 

 

The MS SQL service should then start.


NOTE : You may be required to reattach the existing databases to the instance depending on what was lost when the master db corrupted. 

 

If the above fails then there is another method but it has pitfalls. 

 

Manually Recreating the Master Database

 

The below method will work however it will remove all users from the instance making logging in and administration very difficult. This method should be used as a last ditch effort to get the system up and running. It may be preferable to reinstall SQL completely over the below. 

 

Before running this make sure you have copies of the existing model and msdb databases saved off somewhere safe!

 

Navigate to your instance folder "C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\MSSQL.1\MSSQL " , there you will find a folder called Template Data, copy the master.mdf and mastlog.ldf from Template Data and replace it in "C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\MSSQL.1\MSSQL\Data"

 

NOTE : You WILL be required to reattach the existing databases to the instance. You WILL be required to recreate any SQL users

 

Restart the MS SQL Service and it will come back online

title: Database (Suspect) Mode
text: Database (Suspect) Mode 29. marts 2023 16:59 If a database is showing as suspect in SSMS this usually means there is an integrity issue between with data file (mdf) and the log file (ldf). Sometimes however it can be a red herring. Before attempting the below it is worth a restart of the SQL service to see if the database will come back online. If that doesn't work then it is best practice to restore from the last good backup. If a backup isn't available and the database does not recover after a restart then the below procedure should be attempted. Step 1: Put the database in EMERGENCY mode Change the database status to EMERGENCY mode. Doing so, will provide users read-only access to the database. The basic purpose of changing the database mode to emergency is troubleshooting what resulted in database suspect mode issue. To change the database status to EMERGENCY mode, run the below T-SQL query: ALTER DATABASE dbName SET EMERGENCY (dbName could be POS or POS CONFIG) Once you have changed the database status, you will be able to access the db. Step 2: Check database integrity Next, execute Database Console Command (DBCC) CHECKDB. The command helps check the logical and physical integrity of the specified database. If it finds any problem with the database, it recommends appropriate repair options such as ‘REPAIR_REBUILD’, ‘REPAIR_FAST’, or ‘REPAIR_ALLOW_DATA_LOSS’. Use the following query to run DBCC CHECKDB: DBCC CHECKDB ('dbName') (dbName could be POS or POS CONFIG, depending on which one is in Suspect mode) Suggestion: Make sure to run the DBCC CHECKDB command regularly to check for physical and logical integrity of the database. Step 3: Set database in SINGLE_USER mode Now run the below T-SQL query to rollback any transaction and bring the SQL database to Single User mode. ALTER DATABASE dbName SET SINGLE_USER WITH ROLLBACK IMMEDIATE Step 4: Repair the database Re-Run DBCC CHECKDB with repair options to repair the suspect database. For this, use the following T-SQL query: DBCC CHECKDB (dbname, REPAIR) WITH NO_INFOMSGS; IF REPAIR alone still produces errors use DBCC CHECKDB (dbname, REPAIR_ALLOW_DATA_LOSS) WITH NO_INFOMSGS Note: DBCC CHECKDB with REPAIR_ALLOW_DATA_LOSS may help you fix all the errors and repair them; however, it can cause data loss from the repaired database. Step 5: Bring the database to MULTI_USER mode If you find that the script runs successfully, bring the database back from single-user mode to multi-user mode. Run the following command to do it: ALTER DATABASE dbName SET MULTI_USER Step 6: Bring the database ONLINE To change the database state from EMERGENCY to ONLINE, execute the following command: ALTER DATABASE dbName SET ONLINE Once repaired and back online immediately backup the database and suggest potential backup solutions to recover from potential future incidents. Fra <https://www.stellarinfo.com/support/kb/index.php/article/procedure-to-recover-sql-database-from-suspect-mode
description:
Database (Suspect) Mode

29. marts 2023

16:59

 

If a database is showing as suspect in SSMS this usually means there is an integrity issue between with data file (mdf) and the log file (ldf). Sometimes however it can be a red herring.

 

Before attempting the below it is worth a restart of the SQL service to see if the database will come back online. If that doesn't work then it is best practice to restore from the last good backup.

 

If a backup isn't available and the database does not recover after a restart then the below procedure should be attempted.

 

Step 1: Put the database in EMERGENCY mode

 

Change the database status to EMERGENCY mode. Doing so, will provide users read-only access to the database. The basic purpose of changing the database mode to emergency is troubleshooting what resulted in database suspect mode issue. 

 

To change the database status to EMERGENCY mode, run the below T-SQL query:

 

ALTER DATABASE  dbName  SET  EMERGENCY (dbName could be POS or POS CONFIG)

 

Once you have changed the database status, you will be able to access the db.

 

Step 2: Check database integrity

 

Next, execute Database Console Command (DBCC) CHECKDB. The command helps check the logical and physical integrity of the specified database. If it finds any problem with the database, it recommends appropriate repair options such as ‘REPAIR_REBUILD’, ‘REPAIR_FAST’, or ‘REPAIR_ALLOW_DATA_LOSS’.

 

Use the following query to run DBCC CHECKDB:

 

DBCC CHECKDB ('dbName')

 

 (dbName could be POS or POS CONFIG, depending on which one is in Suspect mode)

 

Suggestion: Make sure to run the DBCC CHECKDB command regularly to check for physical and logical integrity of the database.

 

Step 3: Set database in SINGLE_USER mode

Now run the below T-SQL query to rollback any transaction and bring the SQL database to Single User mode.

 

ALTER DATABASE dbName SET SINGLE_USER WITH ROLLBACK IMMEDIATE

 

Step 4: Repair the database

Re-Run DBCC CHECKDB with repair options to repair the suspect database. For this, use the following T-SQL query:

 

DBCC CHECKDB (dbname, REPAIR) WITH NO_INFOMSGS; IF REPAIR alone still produces errors use DBCC CHECKDB (dbname, REPAIR_ALLOW_DATA_LOSS) WITH NO_INFOMSGS

 

Note: DBCC CHECKDB with REPAIR_ALLOW_DATA_LOSS may help you fix all the errors and repair them; however, it can cause data loss from the repaired database.

 

Step 5: Bring the database to MULTI_USER mode

 

If you find that the script runs successfully, bring the database back from single-user mode to multi-user mode. Run the following command to do it:

 

ALTER DATABASE dbName SET MULTI_USER

 

Step 6: Bring the database ONLINE

 

To change the database state from EMERGENCY to ONLINE, execute the following command:

 

ALTER DATABASE dbName SET ONLINE

 

Once repaired and back online immediately backup the database and suggest potential backup solutions to recover from potential future incidents. 

 

Fra <https://www.stellarinfo.com/support/kb/index.php/article/procedure-to-recover-sql-database-from-suspect-mode

title: Display all tables and sizes
text: Display all tables and sizes vrijdag 23 september 2022 11:01 SQL DISPLAY ALL TABLES AND SIZE SELECT t.NAME AS TableName, i.name as indexName, p.[Rows], sum(a.total_pages) as TotalPages, sum(a.used_pages) as UsedPages, sum(a.data_pages) as DataPages, (sum(a.total_pages) * 8) / 1024 as TotalSpaceMB, (sum(a.used_pages) * 8) / 1024 as UsedSpaceMB, (sum(a.data_pages) * 8) / 1024 as DataSpaceMB FROM sys.tables t INNER JOIN sys.indexes i ON t.OBJECT_ID = i.object_id INNER JOIN sys.partitions p ON i.object_id = p.OBJECT_ID AND i.index_id = p.index_id INNER JOIN sys.allocation_units a ON p.partition_id = a.container_id WHERE t.NAME NOT LIKE 'dt%' AND i.OBJECT_ID > 255 AND i.index_id <= 1 GROUP BY t.NAME, i.object_id, i.index_id, i.name, p.[Rows] ORDER BY object_name(i.object_id)
description:
Display all tables and sizes

vrijdag 23 september 2022

11:01

 

SQL DISPLAY ALL TABLES AND SIZE

 

SELECT 

    t.NAME AS TableName,

    i.name as indexName,

    p.[Rows],

    sum(a.total_pages) as TotalPages, 

    sum(a.used_pages) as UsedPages, 

    sum(a.data_pages) as DataPages,

    (sum(a.total_pages) * 8) / 1024 as TotalSpaceMB, 

    (sum(a.used_pages) * 8) / 1024 as UsedSpaceMB, 

    (sum(a.data_pages) * 8) / 1024 as DataSpaceMB

FROM 

    sys.tables t

INNER JOIN      

    sys.indexes i ON t.OBJECT_ID = i.object_id

INNER JOIN 

    sys.partitions p ON i.object_id = p.OBJECT_ID AND i.index_id = p.index_id

INNER JOIN 

    sys.allocation_units a ON p.partition_id = a.container_id

WHERE 

    t.NAME NOT LIKE 'dt%' AND

    i.OBJECT_ID > 255 AND   

    i.index_id <= 1

GROUP BY 

    t.NAME, i.object_id, i.index_id, i.name, p.[Rows]

ORDER BY 

    object_name(i.object_id)

title: Edit more than 200 rows in SQL Server Management Studio
text: Edit more than 200 rows in SQL Server Management Studio 18. januar 2023 13:48 1) From the top menu, click Tools tab and select Options... 2) In the options window, select SQL Server Object Explorer -> Commands. 3) Finally, in Table and View Options, change the value from 200 to a larger value like (2000) in Value for Edit Top Rows command. See the image. 4) Press Ok. It's done. Now you can edit 2000 rows (or any larger value that you have selected) in a table.
description:
Edit more than 200 rows in SQL Server Management Studio

18. januar 2023

13:48

 

1) From the top menu, click Tools tab and select Options...

2) In the options window, select SQL Server Object Explorer -> Commands.

3) Finally, in Table and View Options, change the value from 200 to a larger value like (2000) in Value for Edit Top <n> Rows command. See the image.

4) Press Ok. It's done. Now you can edit 2000 rows (or any larger value that you have selected) in a table.

title: Export to csv with headers
text: Export to csv with headers maandag 19 december 2022 10:45 When you want to export a query result to a csv file there are default no headers exported. There is a liithe bit hidden option where you can set that also headers must be included in your export.
description:
Export to csv with headers

maandag 19 december 2022

10:45

When you want to export a query result to a csv file there are default no headers exported.

 

There is a liithe bit hidden option where you can set that also headers must be included in your export.

title: Find a random Value In SQL-Database
text: Find a random Value In SQL-Database vrijdag 23 september 2022 11:00 DECLARE @SearchStrTableName nvarchar(255), @SearchStrColumnName nvarchar(255), @SearchStrColumnValue nvarchar(255), @SearchStrInXML bit, @FullRowResult bit, @FullRowResultRows int SET @SearchStrColumnValue = '%searchstring%' /* use LIKE syntax */ SET @FullRowResult = 1 SET @FullRowResultRows = 3 SET @SearchStrTableName = NULL /* NULL for all tables, uses LIKE syntax */ SET @SearchStrColumnName = NULL /* NULL for all columns, uses LIKE syntax */ SET @SearchStrInXML = 0 /* Searching XML data may be slow */ IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#Results') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #Results CREATE TABLE #Results (TableName nvarchar(128), ColumnName nvarchar(128), ColumnValue nvarchar(max),ColumnType nvarchar(20)) SET NOCOUNT ON DECLARE @TableName nvarchar(256) = '',@ColumnName nvarchar(128),@ColumnType nvarchar(20), @QuotedSearchStrColumnValue nvarchar(110), @QuotedSearchStrColumnName nvarchar(110) SET @QuotedSearchStrColumnValue = QUOTENAME(@SearchStrColumnValue,'''') DECLARE @ColumnNameTable TABLE (COLUMN_NAME nvarchar(128),DATA_TYPE nvarchar(20)) WHILE @TableName IS NOT NULL BEGIN SET @TableName = ( SELECT MIN(QUOTENAME(TABLE_SCHEMA) + '.' + QUOTENAME(TABLE_NAME)) FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES WHERE TABLE_TYPE = 'BASE TABLE' AND TABLE_NAME LIKE COALESCE(@SearchStrTableName,TABLE_NAME) AND QUOTENAME(TABLE_SCHEMA) + '.' + QUOTENAME(TABLE_NAME) > @TableName AND OBJECTPROPERTY(OBJECT_ID(QUOTENAME(TABLE_SCHEMA) + '.' + QUOTENAME(TABLE_NAME)), 'IsMSShipped') = 0 ) IF @TableName IS NOT NULL BEGIN DECLARE @sql VARCHAR(MAX) SET @sql = 'SELECT QUOTENAME(COLUMN_NAME),DATA_TYPE FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS WHERE TABLE_SCHEMA = PARSENAME(''' + @TableName + ''', 2) AND TABLE_NAME = PARSENAME(''' + @TableName + ''', 1) AND DATA_TYPE IN (' + CASE WHEN ISNUMERIC(REPLACE(REPLACE(REPLACE(REPLACE(REPLACE(@SearchStrColumnValue,'%',''),'_',''),'[',''),']',''),'-','')) = 1 THEN '''tinyint'',''int'',''smallint'',''bigint'',''numeric'',''decimal'',''smallmoney'',''money'',' ELSE '' END + '''char'',''varchar'',''nchar'',''nvarchar'',''timestamp'',''uniqueidentifier''' + CASE @SearchStrInXML WHEN 1 THEN ',''xml''' ELSE '' END + ') AND COLUMN_NAME LIKE COALESCE(' + CASE WHEN @SearchStrColumnName IS NULL THEN 'NULL' ELSE '''' + @SearchStrColumnName + '''' END + ',COLUMN_NAME)' INSERT INTO @ColumnNameTable EXEC (@sql) WHILE EXISTS (SELECT TOP 1 COLUMN_NAME FROM @ColumnNameTable) BEGIN PRINT @ColumnName SELECT TOP 1 @ColumnName = COLUMN_NAME,@ColumnType = DATA_TYPE FROM @ColumnNameTable SET @sql = 'SELECT ''' + @TableName + ''',''' + @ColumnName + ''',' + CASE @ColumnType WHEN 'xml' THEN 'LEFT(CAST(' + @ColumnName + ' AS nvarchar(MAX)), 4096),''' WHEN 'timestamp' THEN 'master.dbo.fn_varbintohexstr('+ @ColumnName + '),''' ELSE 'LEFT(' + @ColumnName + ', 4096),''' END + @ColumnType + ''' FROM ' + @TableName + ' (NOLOCK) ' + ' WHERE ' + CASE @ColumnType WHEN 'xml' THEN 'CAST(' + @ColumnName + ' AS nvarchar(MAX))' WHEN 'timestamp' THEN 'master.dbo.fn_varbintohexstr('+ @ColumnName + ')' ELSE @ColumnName END + ' LIKE ' + @QuotedSearchStrColumnValue INSERT INTO #Results EXEC(@sql) IF @@ROWCOUNT > 0 IF @FullRowResult = 1 BEGIN SET @sql = 'SELECT TOP ' + CAST(@FullRowResultRows AS VARCHAR(3)) + ' ''' + @TableName + ''' AS [TableFound],''' + @ColumnName + ''' AS [ColumnFound],''FullRow>'' AS [FullRow>],*' + ' FROM ' + @TableName + ' (NOLOCK) ' + ' WHERE ' + CASE @ColumnType WHEN 'xml' THEN 'CAST(' + @ColumnName + ' AS nvarchar(MAX))' WHEN 'timestamp' THEN 'master.dbo.fn_varbintohexstr('+ @ColumnName + ')' ELSE @ColumnName END + ' LIKE ' + @QuotedSearchStrColumnValue EXEC(@sql) END DELETE FROM @ColumnNameTable WHERE COLUMN_NAME = @ColumnName END END END SET NOCOUNT OFF SELECT TableName, ColumnName, ColumnValue, ColumnType, COUNT(*) AS Count FROM #Results GROUP BY TableName, ColumnName, ColumnValue, ColumnType
description:
Find a random Value In SQL-Database

vrijdag 23 september 2022

11:00

 

DECLARE @SearchStrTableName nvarchar(255), @SearchStrColumnName nvarchar(255), @SearchStrColumnValue nvarchar(255), @SearchStrInXML bit, @FullRowResult bit, @FullRowResultRows int

SET @SearchStrColumnValue = '%searchstring%' /* use LIKE syntax */

SET @FullRowResult = 1

SET @FullRowResultRows = 3

SET @SearchStrTableName = NULL /* NULL for all tables, uses LIKE syntax */

SET @SearchStrColumnName = NULL /* NULL for all columns, uses LIKE syntax */

SET @SearchStrInXML = 0 /* Searching XML data may be slow */

 

IF OBJECT_ID('tempdb..#Results') IS NOT NULL DROP TABLE #Results

CREATE TABLE #Results (TableName nvarchar(128), ColumnName nvarchar(128), ColumnValue nvarchar(max),ColumnType nvarchar(20))

 

SET NOCOUNT ON

 

DECLARE @TableName nvarchar(256) = '',@ColumnName nvarchar(128),@ColumnType nvarchar(20), @QuotedSearchStrColumnValue nvarchar(110), @QuotedSearchStrColumnName nvarchar(110)

SET @QuotedSearchStrColumnValue = QUOTENAME(@SearchStrColumnValue,'''')

DECLARE @ColumnNameTable TABLE (COLUMN_NAME nvarchar(128),DATA_TYPE nvarchar(20))

 

WHILE @TableName IS NOT NULL

BEGIN

    SET @TableName = 

    (

        SELECT MIN(QUOTENAME(TABLE_SCHEMA) + '.' + QUOTENAME(TABLE_NAME))

        FROM    INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES

        WHERE       TABLE_TYPE = 'BASE TABLE'

            AND TABLE_NAME LIKE COALESCE(@SearchStrTableName,TABLE_NAME)

            AND QUOTENAME(TABLE_SCHEMA) + '.' + QUOTENAME(TABLE_NAME) > @TableName

            AND OBJECTPROPERTY(OBJECT_ID(QUOTENAME(TABLE_SCHEMA) + '.' + QUOTENAME(TABLE_NAME)), 'IsMSShipped') = 0

    )

    IF @TableName IS NOT NULL

    BEGIN

        DECLARE @sql VARCHAR(MAX)

        SET @sql = 'SELECT QUOTENAME(COLUMN_NAME),DATA_TYPE

                FROM    INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS

                WHERE       TABLE_SCHEMA    = PARSENAME(''' + @TableName + ''', 2)

                AND TABLE_NAME  = PARSENAME(''' + @TableName + ''', 1)

                AND DATA_TYPE IN (' + CASE WHEN ISNUMERIC(REPLACE(REPLACE(REPLACE(REPLACE(REPLACE(@SearchStrColumnValue,'%',''),'_',''),'[',''),']',''),'-','')) = 1 THEN '''tinyint'',''int'',''smallint'',''bigint'',''numeric'',''decimal'',''smallmoney'',''money'',' ELSE '' END + '''char'',''varchar'',''nchar'',''nvarchar'',''timestamp'',''uniqueidentifier''' + CASE @SearchStrInXML WHEN 1 THEN ',''xml''' ELSE '' END + ')

                AND COLUMN_NAME LIKE COALESCE(' + CASE WHEN @SearchStrColumnName IS NULL THEN 'NULL' ELSE '''' + @SearchStrColumnName + '''' END  + ',COLUMN_NAME)'

        INSERT INTO @ColumnNameTable

        EXEC (@sql)

        WHILE EXISTS (SELECT TOP 1 COLUMN_NAME FROM @ColumnNameTable)

        BEGIN

            PRINT @ColumnName

            SELECT TOP 1 @ColumnName = COLUMN_NAME,@ColumnType = DATA_TYPE FROM @ColumnNameTable

            SET @sql = 'SELECT ''' + @TableName + ''',''' + @ColumnName + ''',' + CASE @ColumnType WHEN 'xml' THEN 'LEFT(CAST(' + @ColumnName + ' AS nvarchar(MAX)), 4096),''' 

            WHEN 'timestamp' THEN 'master.dbo.fn_varbintohexstr('+ @ColumnName + '),'''

            ELSE 'LEFT(' + @ColumnName + ', 4096),''' END + @ColumnType + ''' 

                    FROM ' + @TableName + ' (NOLOCK) ' +

                    ' WHERE ' + CASE @ColumnType WHEN 'xml' THEN 'CAST(' + @ColumnName + ' AS nvarchar(MAX))' 

                    WHEN 'timestamp' THEN 'master.dbo.fn_varbintohexstr('+ @ColumnName + ')'

                    ELSE @ColumnName END + ' LIKE ' + @QuotedSearchStrColumnValue

            INSERT INTO #Results

            EXEC(@sql)

            IF @@ROWCOUNT > 0 IF @FullRowResult = 1 

            BEGIN

                SET @sql = 'SELECT TOP ' + CAST(@FullRowResultRows AS VARCHAR(3)) + ' ''' + @TableName + ''' AS [TableFound],''' + @ColumnName + ''' AS [ColumnFound],''FullRow>'' AS [FullRow>],*' +

                    ' FROM ' + @TableName + ' (NOLOCK) ' +

                    ' WHERE ' + CASE @ColumnType WHEN 'xml' THEN 'CAST(' + @ColumnName + ' AS nvarchar(MAX))' 

                    WHEN 'timestamp' THEN 'master.dbo.fn_varbintohexstr('+ @ColumnName + ')'

                    ELSE @ColumnName END + ' LIKE ' + @QuotedSearchStrColumnValue

                EXEC(@sql)

            END

            DELETE FROM @ColumnNameTable WHERE COLUMN_NAME = @ColumnName

        END 

    END

END

SET NOCOUNT OFF

 

SELECT TableName, ColumnName, ColumnValue, ColumnType, COUNT(*) AS Count FROM #Results

GROUP BY TableName, ColumnName, ColumnValue, ColumnType

title: Overview SQL backups (and type) of a particular DB
text: Overview SQL backups (and type) of a particular DB vrijdag 23 september 2022 10:57 SELECT A.Type, CASE WHEN Type = 'D' THEN 'Database Full' WHEN Type = 'I' THEN 'Differential database' WHEN Type = 'L' THEN 'Log' WHEN Type = 'F' THEN 'File or Filegroup' WHEN Type = 'G' THEN 'Differential file' WHEN Type = 'P' THEN 'Partial' WHEN Type = 'Q' THEN 'Differential partial' END, A.database_name, B.physical_device_name,A.media_set_id,A.backup_size, A.backup_start_date,A.backup_finish_date, a.*, b.* FROM msdb.dbo.backupset A INNER JOIN msdb.dbo.backupmediafamily B ON A.media_set_id = B.media_set_id WHERE A.Database_Name= 'DRSContacts' ORDER BY A.backup_finish_date DESC
description:
Overview SQL backups (and type) of a particular DB

vrijdag 23 september 2022

10:57

 

SELECT A.Type, 

CASE 

      WHEN Type = 'D' THEN 'Database Full'

      WHEN Type = 'I' THEN 'Differential database'

      WHEN Type = 'L' THEN 'Log'

      WHEN Type = 'F' THEN 'File or Filegroup'

      WHEN Type = 'G' THEN 'Differential file'

      WHEN Type = 'P' THEN 'Partial'

      WHEN Type = 'Q' THEN 'Differential partial'

END,

A.database_name, B.physical_device_name,A.media_set_id,A.backup_size,

A.backup_start_date,A.backup_finish_date, a.*, b.*

FROM msdb.dbo.backupset A

INNER JOIN msdb.dbo.backupmediafamily B

ON A.media_set_id = B.media_set_id

WHERE A.Database_Name= 'DRSContacts'

ORDER BY A.backup_finish_date DESC

title: Recovery Pending
text: Recovery Pending 25 May 2022 11:36 If the POS will not open, check the database in Microsoft SQL Management Studio. If a database is marked as Recovery Pending, you have to run the below query to unlock it. Replace [DBName] with the appropriate database name (e.g. POS or the shop name) ALTER DATABASE [DBName] SET EMERGENCY; GO ALTER DATABASE [DBName] set single_user GO DBCC CHECKDB ([DBName], REPAIR_ALLOW_DATA_LOSS) WITH ALL_ERRORMSGS; GO ALTER DATABASE [DBName] set multi_user GO
description:
Recovery Pending

25 May 2022

11:36

 

If the POS will not open, check the database in Microsoft SQL Management Studio.

 

If a database is marked as Recovery Pending, you have to run the below query to unlock it. Replace [DBName] with the appropriate database name (e.g. POS or the shop name)

 

 

ALTER DATABASE [DBName] SET EMERGENCY; 

 

GO 

 

ALTER DATABASE [DBName] set single_user 

 

GO 

 

DBCC CHECKDB ([DBName], REPAIR_ALLOW_DATA_LOSS) WITH ALL_ERRORMSGS; 

 

GO 

 

ALTER DATABASE [DBName] set multi_user 

 

GO

title: SQL Version Cheat Sheet

title: Timestamp in MS SQL
text: Timestamp in MS SQL vrijdag 23 september 2022 10:53 Timestamp in MS SQL Question from a web builder from one of our customers Do you know what the timestamp of September 1, 2022 is? The question was: I would like to run an import from September 1st, but I don't know exactly how to set up the timestamp. What I see in the code is that we take over the timestamp and compare it with the Timestamp field of a contact from your system. For example, a timestamp of today is 9532942. Could you tell me what that is from September 1, 2022 0:00? Answer: We have had this question before and unfortunately a Timestamp is not as the name suggests an equivalent of a date and time. See also explanation below. There are various forums where this is explained, but you just have to see the code as a kind of tracking number. As soon as an UPDATE is performed on a record, a trigger is called that updates RecModified to the current system date (from where the database is running) The RecTimeStamp will also be adjusted. Incidentally, in the forums you can also read that in MS SQl TimeStamp is marked as depricated. In other words, marked as no longer usable, because it will (possibly) be removed. TIMESTAMP in SQL This datatype is also known as "rowversion", and the original name is really unfortunate. A timestamp column is automatically updated whenever a row is updated, and the value is monotonically increasing in the database. There is absolutely no relation to date and time. The main purpose of timestamp is to implement optimistic concurrency. The client reads a row from the database gets the timestamp value from the database and sends it back on UPDATE. The UPDATE operation includes a condition on timestamp in the WHERE clause, and if the timestamp value has changed since the client read the value, the update is not performed - and the update that came in-between is not lost. timestamp/rowversion does not seem to be that popular these days, but I have worked with a system where have many of these columns for exactly this reason. Because it is monotonically increasing, some people also use it to find the most recently changed rows in a table, but this is not what it is designed for, and it does not work well in high-concurrency environment. SQL Server offers better features for this purpose, for instance Change Tracking. Example: Customer 111903 LastChanged: 01-12-2016 has Timestamp 0x0000000000255C0F Converted to a date with https://www.epochconverter.com/: 29-01-1970 If we change this customer, the new Timestamp will be: 0x00000000007D80F2 Converted to date: 06-04-1970 So there's not really a logic to it. Therefore, we cannot specify what the Timestamp is on a certain date.
description:
Timestamp in MS SQL

vrijdag 23 september 2022

10:53

 

Timestamp in MS SQL

 

Question from a web builder from one of our customers

Do you know what the timestamp of September 1, 2022 is?

 

The question was:

I would like to run an import from September 1st, but I don't know exactly how to set up the timestamp. What I see in the code is that we take over the timestamp and compare it with the Timestamp field of a contact from your system. 

For example, a timestamp of today is 9532942. 

Could you tell me what that is from September 1, 2022 0:00? 

 

Answer:

We have had this question before and unfortunately a Timestamp is not as the name suggests an equivalent of a date and time.

See also explanation below.

There are various forums where this is explained, but you just have to see the code as a kind of tracking number.

 

As soon as an UPDATE is performed on a record, a trigger is called that updates RecModified to the current system date (from where the database is running) 

The RecTimeStamp will also be adjusted.

Incidentally, in the forums you can also read that in MS SQl TimeStamp is marked as depricated. In other words, marked as no longer usable, because it will (possibly) be removed.

 

TIMESTAMP in SQL

This datatype is also known as "rowversion", and the original name is really unfortunate.

A timestamp column is automatically updated whenever a row is updated, and the value is monotonically increasing in the database. There is absolutely no relation to date and time.

The main purpose of timestamp is to implement optimistic concurrency. The client reads a row from the database gets the timestamp value from the database and sends it back on UPDATE.

The UPDATE operation includes a condition on timestamp in the WHERE clause, and if the timestamp value has changed since the client read the value, the update is not performed - and the update that came in-between is not lost.

timestamp/rowversion does not seem to be that popular these days, but I have worked with a system where have many of these columns for exactly this reason.

Because it is monotonically increasing, some people also use it to find the most recently changed rows in a table, but this is not what it is designed for, and it does not work well in high-concurrency environment. SQL Server offers better features for this purpose, for instance Change Tracking.

 

Example:

 

Customer 111903 LastChanged: 01-12-2016 has Timestamp  0x0000000000255C0F

 

 

 Converted to a date with https://www.epochconverter.com/: 29-01-1970

 

 

If we change this customer, the new Timestamp will be: 0x00000000007D80F2

 

 

 

Converted to date: 06-04-1970

 

 

So there's not really a logic to it.

Therefore, we cannot specify what the Timestamp is on a certain date.

title: Understanding SQL locks
text: Understanding SQL locks vrijdag 23 september 2022 10:59 Locking Locking is the situation where a table is exclusively locked for 1 session to do an update or delete. Others will have to wait if they want to update or delete on the same table. Mr Blue updates some data, therefor locks the table so he has exclusive access. Mrs Green does the same, but instead on a different table. Both are not experiencing any performance loss or other problems. Blocking Blocking is the situation where a table is exclusively locked for 1 session to do an update or delete. Others are waiting for the first session to finish before they can update or delete on that same table. Mr Blue updates some data, therefor locks table A so he has exclusive access. Mrs Green also wants to update Table A, but she has to wait for Mr Blue to finish. And she will wait forever, until Mr Blue is finished. This can result in Mrs Green experiencing loss of performance loss. Applications usually have some kind of timeout, so it is to be expected that when this all takes too long, a timeout error will occur. Deadlocking Deadlocking is the situation where 2 or more sessions are running updates or deletes on multiple tables and are waiting for each other to finish work on a table they need access to, so they can finish their work. Mr Blue started a session where he will be updating Table A and later on he also needs to update Table B. In the mean time Mrs Green started a session where she is updating Table B. And she also needs to do an update on Table A in that same session. Mr Blue holds the lock on Table A, while he waits for Mrs Green to finish work on Table B. Mrs Green holds the lock on Table B, while she waits for Mr Blue to finish work on Table A. This has now turned into a Mexican standoff that they can’t figure out themselves. Now SQL Server steps in and makes a decision and simply kills one of the two sessions and all changes in that session will be rollbacked. SQL Server will base the decision on what he thinks is simplest for him to rollback. This can result in some feelings of bad performance, as SQL Server can take up to 5 seconds before making the decision to kill a deadlock situation. But more important: The session that was killed and rolled back has lost its data! It’s up to the process performing the query (probably an application) to retry the query. Although this sounds simple, most of the time this does not happen and data is lost forever. WITH (NOLOCK) In order not to have a problem with locking, we often see the use of the WITH (NOLOCK) query option to bypass locking and speeding up performance when running SELECT statements. However, using this option, you will also see data that SQL Server is still processing. You are likely to get results back that are being changed as you run the query. Your query is returning ‘dirty’ results. And when accuracy is needed, these results can be disastrously off! Both these selects get the same results when there are no updates running. But watch what happens if we start a second session where updates are being done to the same table but different records. Note: The SELECT statements looks for all users with DisplayName is ‘alex’. The UPDATE statement explicitly updates all records where DisplayName does not equals ‘alex’. From the results of the SELECT statement you can clearly see they are constantly changing, although that data is not being changed! If we would depend on the numbers of this query being accurate, we will fail big time. But using WITH (NOLOCK) can be useful when accuracy is not an issue. For example, if we would query a queue. If we see the queue length rising, this is an indication that we must act for example to check if there isn’t an application down. In this case, it doesn’t really matter that our numbers are correct. Continuous monitoring is what counts here.
description:
Understanding SQL locks

vrijdag 23 september 2022

10:59

Locking

Locking is the situation where a table is exclusively locked for 1 session to do an update or delete. Others will have to wait if they want to update or delete on the same table.

Mr Blue updates some data, therefor locks the table so he has exclusive access. Mrs Green does the same, but instead on a different table. Both are not experiencing any performance loss or other problems.

 

 

 

 

Blocking

Blocking is the situation where a table is exclusively locked for 1 session to do an update or delete. Others are waiting for the first session to finish before they can update or delete on that same table.

Mr Blue updates some data, therefor locks table A so he has exclusive access. Mrs Green also wants to update Table A, but she has to wait for Mr Blue to finish. And she will wait forever, until Mr Blue is finished. This can result in Mrs Green experiencing loss of performance loss. Applications usually have some kind of timeout, so it is to be expected that when this all takes too long, a timeout error will occur.

 

 

 

 

Deadlocking

Deadlocking is the situation where 2 or more sessions are running updates or deletes on multiple tables and are waiting for each other to finish work on a table they need access to, so they can finish their work.

Mr Blue started a session where he will be updating Table A and later on he also needs to update Table B. In the mean time Mrs Green started a session where she is updating Table B. And she also needs to do an update on Table A in that same session.

Mr Blue holds the lock on Table A, while he waits for Mrs Green to finish work on Table B.

Mrs Green holds the lock on Table B, while she waits for Mr Blue to finish work on Table A.

This has now turned into a Mexican standoff that they can’t figure out themselves. Now SQL Server steps in and makes a decision and simply kills one of the two sessions and all changes in that session will be rollbacked. SQL Server will base the decision on what he thinks is simplest for him to rollback.

This can result in some feelings of bad performance, as SQL Server can take up to 5 seconds before making the decision to kill a deadlock situation. But more important: The session that was killed and rolled back has lost its data! It’s up to the process performing the query (probably an application) to retry the query. Although this sounds simple, most of the time this does not happen and data is lost forever.

 

 

 

 

WITH (NOLOCK)

In order not to have a problem with locking, we often see the use of the WITH (NOLOCK) query option to bypass locking and speeding up performance when running SELECT statements. However, using this option, you will also see data that SQL Server is still processing. You are likely to get results back that are being changed as you run the query.

Your query is returning ‘dirty’ results. And when accuracy is needed, these results can be disastrously off!

Both these selects get the same results when there are no updates running.

 

 

 

But watch what happens if we start a second session where updates are being done to the same table but different records. 

Note: The SELECT statements looks for all users with DisplayName is ‘alex’. The UPDATE statement explicitly updates all records where DisplayName does not equals ‘alex’.

From the results of the SELECT statement you can clearly see they are constantly changing, although that data is not being changed! If we would depend on the numbers of this query being accurate, we will fail big time.

 

 

 

But using WITH (NOLOCK) can be useful when accuracy is not an issue. For example, if we would query a queue. If we see the queue length rising, this is an indication that we must act for example to check if there isn’t an application down. In this case, it doesn’t really matter that our numbers are correct. Continuous monitoring is what counts here.

title: Find Common String Of Letters In Columns In All Tables In SQL Database
text: If you would like to find all columns that has the same string of letters in them, in case you are trying to find foreign keys in other tables that is linked to a primary key in a table, use the below SQL: SELECT c.name AS 'ColumnName', t.name AS 'TableName' FROM sys.columns c JOIN sys.tables t ON c.object_id = t.object_id WHERE c.name LIKE '%Insert Here%' AND t.name NOT LIKE 'BAK%' ORDER BY TableName, ColumnName;
description:
If you would like to find all columns that has the same string of letters in them, in case you are trying to find foreign keys in other tables that is linked to a primary key in a table, use the below SQL:


SELECT c.name AS 'ColumnName', t.name AS 'TableName' 
FROM sys.columns c 
JOIN sys.tables  t ON c.object_id = t.object_id 
WHERE c.name LIKE '%Insert Here%' AND t.name NOT LIKE 'BAK%' 
ORDER BY TableName, ColumnName;
